msDesc.head: Recipes for medicines, pigments, inks, and astrological tracts

msItem.title: Treatise on making pigments and bonding agents
msItem.rubric: 1r Grammatica docet recte [...] recte scribere Ex quo patet [...] in 2as partes primo de prima parte [...] est de recta scriptura Sunt autem instrumenta eius color et materia super quae debet scribi
msItem.incipit: 1r Sunt autem due colores principales scilicet albedo et nigrido ceteri autem colores componuntur ex istis
msItem.explicit: 7r et est optimus viscus vtere statim eo dum humidus sit
msItem.note: The rubric is partly missing due to damage to the page.

msItem.title: Treatise on various modes of writing from the Liber Cosmographiae
msItem.author: John Foxton
msItem.incipit: 7r Alkemuste [?] in libris suis falsemonas [?] imponunt vij metalla vij nomina planetarum .v. ergo aurum vocatur
msItem.explicit: 15r et tunc remanebit dictus color in litteris inseparabiliter et apparebunt littere pulcherrimae illuminate
msItem.note: The treatise includes sections on cypher, invisible writing, and making illuminated letters.

msItem.title: Added recipe for making bonding agent for erasures
msItem.incipit: 10r [make wet hore pommes with spittel and pot owght the letter and the letter bihng oght than take the meel of whet and temper it with the wheght of a nesse berri and and anoint the plake rassid ther with and let it drie and then wright anew]
msItem.note: Full transcription: the English text is written in Greek script; added to the margins by a later (16th-century) hand.

msItem.title: Treatise on rhethoric from the Secreta Secretorum
msItem.incipit: 11v Caueat ergo qui recte loquere voluerit a multiloquio sicut docet Aristottels Regem Alexandrum quod factatis auribus animi faciantur
msItem.explicit: 15r et sine casu quid verbo tenus videtur valde mirabile at hic
msItem.note: The treatise includes a section on verbal tricks which is accompanied by the drawing of a cross, illustrating a particular example.

msItem.title: Treatise on optical illusions
msItem.incipit: 15r visum a falso vel apperente vero fac
msItem.explicit: 23r euacuatur et decipitur tactus

msItem.title: Treatise on arithmetic
msItem.rubric: 23r Ars metrica docet de numero per se
msItem.incipit: 23v numerali aut discretioni necessario indigenio [?]
msItem.explicit: 25v quot denotat quot graua sunt in longitudine lente
msItem.finalRubric: 25v Isto modo age in omnibus consilaribus [?]

msItem.title: Collection of natural experiments
msItem.incipit: 25v Potes facere ut pirus gerat
msItem.explicit: 33r licet panis non fuerit in se nisi medio [?] calidus
msItem.note: The collection includes a variety of experiments, e.g. how to make a white rose red (and vice versa), how to make a silver coin appear like copper, to make ravens flee, to make fire with a mirror, to make a candle burn on water, and to remove the seal of a sealed letter.

listBibl.bibl: Da Silva Baptista, 'Playing with the Mind' (2023), p. 7 n.5
Da Silva Baptista, 'Recipes to Animate Small Objects' (2023), p. 11 n. 60

msItem.title: Liber aggregationis seu liber secretorum [Experimenta Alberti]
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.incipit: 33r Sicut dicit philosophus omnis sciencia est de quorum bonorum
msItem.explicit: 39r Celidonius [crossed out: Aluis] Vnus rufus Alius niger Rufus involutus in lineo panno vel coreo [...] sub
msItem.note: The prologue introduces four sections on (1) herbs (2) stones (3) fish and (4) land animals, but the text ends abruptly in the second section, in discussing the Swallow Stone.

msItem.title: Tract on Kalends, Nones, and Ides
msItem.incipit: 41r [N]ota kalenda dicitur a calo .as.
msItem.explicit: 41v Et qui prope fuerunt rome possent venire ad nundinas in minoribus nonis
msItem.note: This treatise is similar to a section from the De notitia kalendarum mensium in the Liber Particularis of Michael Scot.

msItem.title: Treatise on the Twelve Signs of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 41r Item xij sunt signa et xij partes in firmamento et in quolibet singno moratur sol 30 diebus
msItem.explicit: 43v sit sine habundancia aquarum

msItem.title: Tract on hernia
msItem.rubric: 44v ffor a man Ã¾at is brokyn within
msItem.incipit: 46v Hernia a is a corupt sifac Ã¾at is to say of Ã¾e litil skyn wherin Ã¾e bowelles Ã¾at ben beneth Ã¾en lappit in which is ful tender and somtyme hit brekes of diuers causes
msItem.explicit: 46v Also Ã¾e Iuis of wild nepe dronkyn with whit wyne ix dayes togeder knyttes anon as saith karaunus

msItem.title: List of debts for the year 1519-1520
msItem.incipit: 47r Memorandum that thes are the parselles foleyng that is awyng vnto the parson of Keppell Seynt John [crossed out: In be] in the xj Èeyer of the Reyn of Kyng Herri the viij
msItem.explicit: 47v Item of barle lx and xviij croppes
msItem.note: The list includes an entry referring to the parson of Dover.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for a healing elixer for all kinds of wounds
msItem.note: For other copies, see Mooney (1995), p. 128.

msItem.title: Collection of 62 medical recipes
msItem.note: Contains a tract on the virtues of betony (ff. 64v-65v); for other copies, see Mooney (1995), p. 161.

msItem.title: Instructions for collecting seven herbs on the days of the week
msItem.textLang: Latin text with English plant names
msItem.rubric: 51r [S]unt septem dies in septimana sic sunt vij herbe principales et quaelibet herba suum habet diem certum, certam horam diei
msItem.incipit: 51r Prima est Arthemesia id est mugwort et debet capi die dominica
msItem.explicit: 51v-52r lac et natura eius est contra flumen natare cuius si folia mascicentur cum dentibus et ponantur super ceram statim aperietur et dissoluit holres [?] compeditos
msItem.note: Despite the inclusion of plant names in English, this text is not included in Mooney (1995).

msItem.title: Three unlucky days of the year
msItem.author: Pseudo-Bede the Venerable
msItem.incipit: 52r Sciendum quod tres sunt dies quibus si masculus vel femina in illis nascatur sine dubio mala morte
msItem.explicit: 52r Et si in hijs tribus diebus homo vel petus natus fuerit sine dubio infra xiiij dies vt dicit beda morietur etcaetera

msItem.title: Text in cypher
msItem.incipit: 68r [Be it knowen unto al men]
msItem.note: Full decryption of the first line that has been encrypted in three different ways, using numbers and dots for vowels, and Greek letters; a fourth encrypted line using (?) mensural notation has not yet been decrypted.
This page is a palimpsest with the erased undertext still partially visible. It consists of a list of words but has not yet been identified; not read with the help of UV light.

msItem.title: Prognostications for the days of the lunar month
msItem.incipit: 68v lluna prima omnibus agendis utilis
msItem.explicit: 70v luna xxxa Eger non nocebit sompnium fiet apertum infra xxxa dies

msItem.title: De minutione sanguinis (Lunary table with lucky and unlucky days for bloodletting)
msItem.incipit: 70v Luna prima - tota die bona
msItem.explicit: 70v luna xxa Non est bona
msItem.note: The text ends abruptly in the 20th day of the lunar month because the next leaf has been cut out.

msItem.title: A recipe for making a spirit
msItem.incipit: 71r Accipe ollam semiplenam vini uel seruisie et fac ignem de carbonibus
msItem.explicit: 71r et merge in aqua et statim ardebit

msItem.title: Tract on the Virtues of Aqua Vitae
msItem.rubric: 71r Hee sunt virtutes aque vite ardentis quas cepi probare
msItem.incipit: 71r Ista aqua secura ponitur in loce balsami naturalis quoniam omnes virtutes habet et licet extedat in virtutibus balsamum naturalem
msItem.explicit: 73v curat spleneticos epaticos epile[p]ticos paraliticos et omnem guttam fragilitatem potatam et illinita curat etcaetera

msItem.title: Recipe for repairing a broken knife or sword
msItem.rubric: 73v Ad firmandum cultellum fractum vel galdium
msItem.incipit: 73v Recipe radicis pollipodij super quercum
msItem.explicit: 73v et cum eadem aqua madefac pecias fractas in iuncturas et repone tenendo directe quousque fuerunt desiccate

msItem.title: Untitled metallurgical recipe
msItem.incipit: 73v Secundum M. W. Recipe auripigmenti lb. scilicet atramenti ana pro coloribus etcaetera

msItem.title: Two recipes for making invisible writing
msItem.incipit: 73v Ad scribendum litteram que non possit legeri nec videri nec tale faciatur ad igne
msItem.explicit: 74r et scribe de isto quicquid volueris

msItem.title: Recipe for making metallic ink to write on a knife or sword
msItem.rubric: 74r Recipe puluerem aluminis et sal gemme et distempera cum vrina et scribe cum illo super cultellum vel gladium
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Collection of 17 recipess
msItem.textLang: Middle English recipes, some with Latin headings
msItem.incipit: 74r[F]or to wryte with metall take lymell of gold or siluer or of any oÃ¾er metell and take quyksiluer and claryfied hony and stere hem wel togidur and grynde hem wel
msItem.explicit: 77v [U]t canes non latrent super te fer super te columbinam contra eos qui loquuntur in nocte lilium cum vino bibant etcaetera
msItem.note: The collection is described as dedicated to metallic inks in Mooney (1995), p. 161. It indeed opens with such recipes, including one for writing with gold or silver that is said to have been proved by a certain 'faskin' (probat est per faskin). However, the collection actually covers a much wider range, including recipes to make spirit ('aqua ardens'), red wax, and gunpowder; to capture fish with your hands; to make someone fall asleep; to cure the 'stone'; to make yourself invisible by placing the heart of a toad on your foot; to prevent dogs from barking at you; and to stop someone from talking in their sleep. The collection also features a charm for finding stolen goods (Pro furto inueniendo) on f. 77v. The latter requires the victim to place a piece of virgin wax inscribed with the names of the Three Magi, Dismas and Gestas, under their head when they go to sleep. After nine nights they will see the location of their goods in a dream.

msItem.title: Three chemical recipes
msItem.incipit: 78r Recipe vitrioli Hungaris exigram, quantitatem contunde in mortario et immitte in aquam communem, et pone iuxta ignem donec omne vitriolum sit solutum: serua aquam hanc ad vsum
msItem.explicit: 78r Ablutio: Recipe Gallas ducis vel tres contunde in mortuario impone in aquam communem, et pone iuxta ignem donec tulluant ; ablues hanc Aquam
msItem.note: Added in a 17th-century hand.

msItem.title: Medical remedies for headache
msItem.note: This text is continued on ff. 80r-80v.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes for healing eye ailments
Medical remedies for headache
msItem.note: This is a continuation of the text on f. 79r.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes are for treating bleedings in the head, clearing sight, and healing cramp and gout. The latter recipe involves a charm that instructs one to make a ring, write the name of St Bernard (presumably on the ring), and daily worship the saint.
Copied by the same hand that copied the recipes on f. 47v.

msItem.title: Five recipes for treating wine
msItem.incipit: 81r Primo pro vino elzatre habentem saporem illius locis in quibus crescunt take Èellow egges and poudre of cynamon half pound and put it to Ã¾e said wyne and so let it rest by a moneth
msItem.explicit: 81v Item for all maner of Rynessh wyn Ã¾at been long and Reching and will not puryfie by theim selff: Take white of egges and clene asshis of wode and a litell Èanelen and put all Ã¾is in re places of Ã¾e same vessell
msItem.note: The recipes refer to Alsace, Rhenish, and mountain (bergh wyn) wine.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for the "stone"
msItem.note: Below the recipe is the name of H Hodykyns; added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Unidentified Latin text
msItem.note: The text consists of three lines, referring to Adreas flagellator.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 83v Dulcia non meruit qui non gustavit amara

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 83v Qui numquam doluit sunt illi [?] gaudio rara

msItem.title: Proverb [unfinished]
msItem.incipit: 83v Si mea penna valet littera

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 83v Dum sumus in mundo vivamus corde iocundo

supportDesc.support: Paper, folded in quarto. Folios 1-39, 41-77, 79-83: various watermarks but mainly an Ox (ff. 40, 78 are early modern paper leaves without watermarks).

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos. '16' omitted by mistake.

list.item: Quire 9thirteen (ff. 71-83: one leaf missing after f. 80, three leaves missing after f. 82)

p.note: M.R. James (1902) suggests that Quire 9 is a sexternion (adding a question mark) but the fact that the thread tackets are visible between f. 81 and a subsequent unfoliated paper stub suggests a larger quire: originally there were at least 7 leaves after f. 81, but 4 leaves have been torn out and remain as unfoliated stubs today.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame only (most pages have vertical lines only but some also have horizontal lines). Single columns. 19-23 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Folios 1r-43v, 48r-67v, 68v-77v, 79r, 80r-80v, have been copied by one or two very similar cursive hand with both secretary and anglicana features.
Folios 44v-46v have been copied by the same cursive hand with both secretary and anglicana features.
The medical recipes on f. 47v, and 81v have been added by the same cursive hand with anglicana features.

The memorandum on f. 47r-47v; medical recipes on ff. 79v, 81v, and 83r; wine recipes on ff. 82r-82v; and proverbs on 83v have been added by different cursive hands with both secretary and anglicana features.
The recipes on f. 78r have been added by a 17th-century Italic hand.

decoNote.p: Marginal drawings in brown ink, illustrating experiments and arguments: a mirror with a sword (f. 14a verso) a tun (f. 15v) and a cross (f. 21v).
One large (3-line) plain red initial on (f. 1r).
Paraphs in red ink on on (f. 1r) only.
Plain initials highlighted in red ink on on (f. 1r) only.

note.p: Modern quire numbers in pencil added to the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires.

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century half vellum binding with purple paper sides.

provenance.p: One of the manuscripts of John Dee (1527â1608) Dee, John, 1527â1608, mathematician, astrologer, and antiquary: identified with an item (MS 34) in the 1583 catalogue of Dee's library (see M.R. James, Catalogue, III (1902), p. 361; Roberts and Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (1990), p. 115]. M.R. James also suggests that the English recipe encrypted with Greek letters in the margins of f. 10r was written by Dee (see James, III, p. 362).

One of the manuscripts of George Carew (1555-1629) Carew, George, 1555-1629, Baron Carew of Clopton and Earl of Totnes: his signature (G: Carew) inscribed in dark ink in the lower margin of f. 1r. Carew is principally known for the collection of books on Irish history that he amassed as an administrator in Ireland between 1574 and 1592. He bequeathed this collection to Sir Thomas Stafford (d. 1655), from whom they passed to William Laud (1573â1645), Archbishop of Canterbury. The latter placed forty-two volumes at Lambeth Library while four reached the Bodleian Library as part of the Laudian collection [see M.R. James, 'The Carew Manuscripts', The English Historical Review, 42:166 (1927), 261-267; James H. Todd, 'Account of an Ancient Irish Manuscript, in the Bodleian Library, Oxford', Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy, 2 (1936-1869), 336-346; and Ute Lotz-Heumann, 'Carew, George, earl of Totnes (1555â1629)', Oxford Dictionary of National Biography (2004)[accessed 23 February 2024]]. About Carew's possession of medieval manuscripts from England much less is known, but these appear to have travelled different routes after they left his collection. His signature (G: Carew) can be found in at least six such medieval manuscripts (besides the present volume):
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.1.57 (f. 1:3v) [previously unidentified as a Carew manuscript] (James, III, pp. 54-58)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.2.22 (f. 1v) (James, III, p. 115)
Edinburgh, University Library, MS 107 (f. 1r) (identified in the online record: 'MS 107: Composite manuscript including twenty-four texts, 13th-14th century')
London, British Library, Harley MS 204 (f. 1r)
London, British library, Harley MS 223 (f. 7r)
London, British Library, Harley MS 234 (f. 1r) (see Andrew G. Watson, The Library of Sir Simonds D'Ewes (London: British Museum, 1966), pp. 210-211 (no. 926); Cyril Ernest Wright, Fontes Harleiani: A Study of the Sources of the Harleian Collection of Manuscripts Preserved in the Department of Manuscripts in the British Museum (London: British Museum, 1972), p. 96)

It is possible that Carew received all these manuscripts from John Dee. Five of the seven aforementioned manuscripts have ownership marks associated with John Dee: while Harley MSS 204, 223, 234, and Trinity College MS O.2.21 all contain his Jupiter-marks, Trinity College MS O.7.23 â which may have featured the Jupiter-mark in the torn off upper margin of f. 1r â has been identified with an item ('M35') in the 1583 catalogue of Dee's library (see Roberts and Watson, John Dee's Library Catalogue (1990), p. 115)].

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1672-1744, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum AngliÃ¦ et HiberniÃ¦ (1697).
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

history.acquisition: Donated to Trinity College by Thomas GaleGale, Thomas, son of Roger Gale (1672-1744), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark O.7.23 are printed separately on three labels pasted on the spine; its current classmark can also be found written on the inside of the front cover (O.7.23), together with the College's printed ex libris featuring its armorial coat of arms, motto (Virtus Vera Nobilitas and name (Coll: Trin: Cant:) engraved by William Stephens, fl. c. 1740-c. 1760 (W. Stephens sculp.); its previous classmarks written on f. 1r: I.2. and 346.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge: A Descriptive Catalogue, Vol. 3 (1902), pp. 361-362 [no. 1351]; and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995), pp. 127-128.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
